title: when is world book day 2019 costume ideas and how to use book tokens
story: Children also get to dress up as their favourite book characters to school.World Book Day is a registered charity that is support by National Book Tokens and brings together UK and Ireland’s publishing industries.It is designated by UNESCO as a worldwide celebration of books and reading and is observed in more than  countries.In the UK and Ireland, World Book Day  is celebrated on Thursday, March .In other countries it is marked on April , the day of William Shakespeares birth.The aim of World Book Day is to celebrate books and reading and is marked in a total of  countries around the world.Both primary schools and secondary schools up and down the country take part as a way of encouraging children to see reading as a hobby.Many schools run special activities to show how reading books can be fun and to allow kids to discover new authors.One of the most well-known activities on World Book Day is when children are invited to go to school dressed as their favourite literary character.From Harry Potter to Willy Wonka and Mary Poppins, some parents outdo themselves in the brilliant costumes they make for their little ones.Also World Book Day provides children with the opportunity to buy a book of their own.Each school pupil from five to  is given a £ token they can redeem against a whole range of paperbacks or audio books.Kids might love it, but for parents, getting the right costume ready for World Book Day can be a pain.With the pressure on, some parents spend a whole lot of time and money transforming their little ones into their favourite book characters.And some of the best often go viral on social media, including the little boy who dressed as Hagrid from Harry Potter and another youngster dressing as Roald Dahls BFG.But for mums and dads who maybe dont have the time , there are a host of easy costume ideas.For example, you could dress your youngster in a duffel coat, hat and wellington boots and transform them into Paddington Bear.A Wheres Wally costume only requires a stripy jumper, bobble hat and a pair of fake glasses.While an easy costume for girls is Pippy Longstocking as you will only need a pair of stripy socks, a dress, and then to plait the hair in pigtails.In partnership with schools, World Book Day organisers will be handing out over  million £ book tokens - which is one for almost every child or young person under  in the UK or Ireland.Those with book tokens can swap them in book shops for one of the ten new World Book Day books - which include a John Green title, an Avengers story and a Paddington tale.The childrens books will be free with a token, and the teen titles will only cost £. when used with one.Alternatively, they can be used to get £ off any full price book instead.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn egged by pro brexit campaigner during visit to mosque
story: The Labour boss was said to have been hit while on a trip to the Muslim Welfare House and Finsbury Park Mosque in North London on Sunday.Sky News reported that the man is said to be a pro-Brexit protester.John Murphy, , was today charged with assault and will appear at Highbury Corner Magistrates Court on March .Murphy allegedly screamed When you vote you get what you vote for as he came from behind and smacked Mr Corbyn with an egg.Diane Abbott, who was with Mr Corbyn at the time, claimed he punched Jeremy very hard and happened to have an egg in his hand.It is understood the alleged attack was not a regular guest at the mosque.politan Police confirmed an egg was thrown at the member of Parliament on Sunday afternoon.Labour sources confirmed Corbyn was unharmed by the event and continued with his programme of events.He was taking part in the annual Visit My Mosque day with Shadow Home secretary Ms Abbott, visiting two venues in his local area.As he went into one he was given several red roses by fans.Mr Corbyn later tweeted: Every year Muslim communities across the country open their doors to people of all faiths and none on #VisitMyMosque Day. Its a fantastic opportunity to build understanding across communities and educate ourselves about our erse communities. Lets build bridges not walls.The Muslim Welfare House in London released a statement after the incident, saying it the attacker had shouted and hurled verbal abuse to the utter shock and disgust of all present.Toufik Kacimi, CEO of the organisation, said: We condemn in the strongest terms this outrageous act which has left everyone shocked.This disgraceful act by this inidual is a sign of the hatred and Islamophobia that sadly abound in our community.We will not let this deter us from cooperating with all groups in building a more cohesive society.Other Labour figures who have been also hit with an egg include ex-Labour boss Ed Miliband, as well as John Prescott, who went on to punch the protester.Last week Mr Corbyn confirmed that his party would get behind a second Brexit referendum, much to the fury of his pro-Brexit voters.But MPs in Leave backing seats warned it could cost the party their seats - and the next election.

title: brexit theresa may departure comment
story: The rebuke was echoed on behalf of .million voters by Tory MP Sir Graham Brady to describe Theresa May’s three miserable years of trench warfare with Brussels.Brexiteer Brady is the respected chairman of the  Committee of Tory MPs, the legendary “Men in grey suits” who have the power, rarely used, to tell leaders their time is up.“All too often it has looked asthe establishment has wanted a Brexit that looks shockingly like not leaving at all,” Mr Brady told a Sunday newspaper.He might have been describing many of those involved in the tortuous Brexit negotiations, but only one name springs to mind.And it will be Mr Brady’s job to hand her the fabled revolver and glass of whisky when that time comes.While it seems increasingly likely Britain is moving crab-like towards some sort of deal on Brexit by March , Mrs May herself is unlikely to long survive its birth.The price of “success” will be for the PM to name the day of her departure from Downing Street.Theresa May will probably have to be dragged kicking and screaming out of No.Having negotiated a deal of sorts, she will feel entitled to tie up loose ends and — more importantly for her — block Boris Johnson as her successor.She is safe from another assassination bid by MPs after seeing off last year’s abortive challenge.But the mood against her has hardened on all sides.Nick Timothy, once her closest ally, now reveals the PM was never able to see the economic upside to leaving the EU and saw Brexit as a problem “to be managed”.Her mantra, “No deal is better than a bad deal”, was meaningless.She and Chancellor Phil Hammond never intended to prepare our ports, freight terminals, tax centres and border controls for a clean-break Brexit.The loathed Northern Ireland backstop was a ruse to keep us so closely aligned that we might as well have stayed in a customs union and therefore the EU itself.From day one, Theresa May was negotiating BRINO — Brexit in Name Only.Her secretive style even infuriated Remainers such as Amber Rudd, who last week broke Cabinet ranks with her own campaign to stop Brexit.Influential Times columnist Matthew Parris, a staunch Remainer, ex-Tory MP and former May supporter, says both Remainers and Brexiteers have turned against the PM.“Theresa May, they tell me, is the Death Star of modern British politics,” Parris says.“Ideas, beliefs, loyalties, affections, trust, whole careers, real men and women, are sucked into the awful void that is Downing Street — and nothing ever comes out. Only a blank so blank that it screams.”But it was “two-dinners” Watson, before his dramatic weight loss, whose “curry house conspiracy” with Gordon Brown toppled triple election-winner Tony Blair.It was Watson who was forced to apologise after using Parliamentary privilege to smear dead Tory Leon Brittan with “evil” child sex slurs.And it is Watson who aims to wreck free speech by gagging the Press.Jew-baiting Marxist Jeremy Corbyn seems a saint by comparison.His bleak imagery will come as no surprise in Westminster, but it explains the tidal wave of ministers who walked out of her Cabinet in exasperation.To her shame, Amber Rudd and her fellow Ruddites lacked the courage to follow suit last week. Instead, they simply destroyed any last chance of using No Deal as a negotiating card.Ms Rudd once saw herself as a potential Tory leader or a “king maker” to Boris Johnson or Michael Gove.“After last week, any association with Amber would be the kiss of death not just in Westminster, but with the party at large,” said a Tory MP.“She is poison. Everyone wants to leave on March  — other than those who don’t want to leave at all.”That prospect now relies on silver-tongued Geoffrey Cox wangling an escape clause on the Northern Ireland backstop — dubbed “Cox’s codpiece”.The Attorney-General needs to sell his formula not just to Theresa May, but to fellow Leavers — including eagle-eyed veteran eurosceptic Bill Cash, chairman of the European Scrutiny Committee.If they approve, Mrs May might clinch Brexit as promised this month.And then navigate her way to a dignied and honourable Therexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the junk food experiment conclusion ally ross opinion
story: With an ITV film crew in tow...  Who captured every last consonant of the resulting explosion she made in the House of Commons cubicle.“THHRRRRRPP.” Then followed it up by zooming in on Nadine’s stool sample, sat as casually as a flapjack next to her cup of tea.All of it captured for the greater glory of The Junk Food Experiment, a Super Size Me rip-off dripping with concern for Britain’s obesity crisis, which attempted to discover what happens to your bodyit’s fed nothing but pizzas, burgers, fried chicken and chips. I know, I know. It really could go either way, that one, couldn’t it  You might end up looking as toned as Joe Wicks — or more like Piers Morgan with an industrial air compressor up his rear.Fortunately, ITV and its diet expert Michael Mosley had gathered “six famous guinea pigs” to gorge themselves stupid and settle this debate for good: Nadine, Hayley Tamaddon off Coronation Street, Peter Andre, Made In Cha’s Hugo Taylor, “Chaser” Shaun Wallace and Tessa Sanderson, who all brought their own degree of hype and range of medical quirks to the experiment.Hayley, for instance, has irritable bowel syndrome, while Hugo suffers from a debilitating strain of irritable personality syndrome and is prone to quoting the Dalai Lama or grandly announcing: “I’m trying to do this for other people. It’s kind of, like, a selfless act.” Or it was, until Hugo decided he couldn’t be arsed and pulled out of the experiment at the end of Week One.The other five kept eating, eating, eating, though, until their bodies began to groan, fart and generally give up on their owners. Hayley and Tessa both had to be withdrawn from the process on health grounds, Shaun Wallace developed sleep apnoea and Nadine began passing “rubber pellets”.One other thing also became apparent during the opening few days of The Junk Food Experiment. Their innards could’ve been begging for mercy and Nadine might well have been on the verge of crapping a cc song, but they all looked exactly the same.It was no sort of spectacle at all, so they tried perking it up with all sorts of production stunts. Peter Andre went for a brain scan that revealed it’s  per cent McFlurry, Michael Mosley entered a competitive eating challenge and Shaun Wallace was sent to his local pub quiz, where he misidentied “the unwanted, loud screeching sounds you sometimes hear from a microphone or speaker” as “white noise” rather than the correct answer, Little Mix.On Day , Nadine also went for another dump — and I don’t know what she was thinking while she sat there, but my mind was wandering to the fact it’s now  years since ITV axed World In Action, a show that was sold around the world and conducted the investigation leading to the release of the Birmingham Six.Here we are now, two decades later, watching six self-publicists come to the the “no-s***, Sherlock” conclusion of the century — eating nothing but pizzas and fast food is bad for you.With the most damning fact of all being that ITV, at the very least, is sending mixed messages about the obesity crisis on its network Hub, where I watched The Junk Food Experiment and every other show received the same promo message.“Sponsored by Domino’s — the official food of unmissable entertainment.”Thanks for your concern, though, ITV. It’s overwhelming.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “In the northern hemisphere, the spring equinox always falls in what month ”Anne: “December.”Ben Shephard: “The Ace Of Spades was a UK Top Ten hit in  for which hard-rock band ”Ang: “N-Dubz.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What McVitie’s chocolate biscuit is named after a flightless bird ”Andy: “Dodo.”Ben Shephard: “In the  film The Rocky Horror Picture Show, which British actor starred as Doctor Frank N Furter ”Tracey: “Sir Anthony Hopkins.”YOU think Theresa May’s got a job on her hands   Spare a thought for the staff on E’s Celebs Go Dating, where they’ve signed up Kerry Katona for the new series. ’Cos that really is the TV equivalent of trying to shove a boulder up Kilimanjaro.Hiring a woman who introduces herself to every potential suitor by announcing: “I’ve got five kids and three ex-husbands, but don’t let that put you off” and describes herself as a “blue-tick shag”, which I thought had wiped out nearly every sheep in West Glamorgan back in .In fairness to Kerry, it does also hint at a level of fame that’s way above the rest of the agency’s clients, who include the thoroughly obnoxious Che Healey, from Hollyoaks, Made In Cha manchild Sam Thompson, Pete Wicks off Towie and someone called David Potts, who could be Mark “The Beast” Labbett’s Chase stunt double, judging by the size of him.None of them, of course, will find anything approaching love on a show where they now boast an impressive  per cent failure rate across six series. title: saving the planet isnt easy daniel hannan
story: She had looked up some old friends in that rainy city and, hearing that they were planning to march from the Gare du Nord to the Gare du Midi to protest about global warming, she decided to tag along.The strikes are spreading all over Europe, inspired by a -year-old Swede called Greta Thunberg, and my daughter was moved by how strongly the demonstrators felt.Then again,you believed you were marching for the survival of the human race, you would feel strongly.The interesting question is whom the youngsters think they are marching against. I mean who, in their imaginations, wants to eliminate the human race It is worth looking at some data. Many of the kids, led by Greta herself, argue that governments are “doing nothing” to reduce carbon emissions.  Not that they are failing to do enough – which is a legitimate argument – but that they are doing nothing.Yet figures published on Monday show an astounding decline in Britain’s CO₂ output. According to statistics released by Carbon Brief,  saw the sixth consecutive fall in the carbon pumped by Britain into the atmosphereTotal emissions are down by  per cent since , a record unmatched by any other major country. With the exception of , the year of the General Strike, you have to go back to  to find a lower level of carbon output.Given the rise in our population in the meantime, that figure is even more impressive. In per capita terms, we have now reduced CO₂ emissions to the level of .You can of course argue that there is still more to do. But “doing nothing”  Seriously  Yet that is indeed the claim being made by eco-activists. They are asserting that governments, including ours, are deliberately wasting time for some reason that no one ever quite explains, but that vaguely has to do with “putting profits before people”.Listen to the way in which the London marchers explained their behaviour in a video put out by the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn. One after another, the young people claimed that they were protesting against people who were quite happy to wreck Planet Earth.“The government doesn’t really care about our future,” said the first demonstrator. “They’re just trying to waste time,” said the second. “I really care about it, because it’s gonna be my kids who wake up and the world’s in pieces,” said the third. “We’re the ones who have to live here,” said the fourth.And where do you suppose the rest of us will be living  I mean, I get that it is tempting to demonise your opponents, but not wanting their own kids to survive  That’s not exactly setting the bar high, is it To be fair, most of us see the world in black-and-white when we’re in our teens. Think back to what you used to read or watch at that age. Young adult literature doesn’t really go in for shades of grey, does it  J.K Rowling doesn’t try to explain what makes the Malfoys nasty. Their nastiness is a given.Some youngsters extend their Harry Potter view of the world into politics, ing the world, not into Leftists and Rightists, but into goodies and baddies. Why would someone want to poison the seas or burn the rainforests  Because – weren’t you listening  – they’re baddies.Most of us eventually learn that le is more complicated than that. For example, Britain has seen huge reductions in its CO₂ emissions because, under Margaret Thatcher, it stopped subsidising unprofitable coalmines. At that time, the sort of people who now march against climate change were marching against the closures.The reason that the United Statesis also seeing a sharp fall in its carbon output is that it is has taken up large-scale fracking – again, a technology that many of the marchers hate.But rehearsing these arguments means acknowledging that things aren’t always simple. It means understanding that there is a trade-off between opportunities for deprived communities and carbon output. It means grasping that most carbon emissions come from China and India. It means recognising the contradiction between “mining coal good” and “burning coal bad”.Most of the marchers will come to understand these things. But some will carry on telling themselves that people who disagree with them are, like the Malfoys, just evil. A few will never grow out of their teen certainties at all. title: england bigger welsh border map gaffe
story: Myrddyn Phillips said the line separating the two countries in the Black Mountains has been wrongly traced on Ordnance Survey maps.The current border follows a line from the summit of a mountain called Twyn Llech.But intrepid Mr Phillips and his hill-walking friend Mark Trengove have re-measured the summit of the ,ft mountain - and found it to be further west.Using a state-of-the art global navigation satellite system, the duo measured the peak of Twyn Llech ft into Powys, Wales.It means there is ,,square feet of land that England is entitled to grab back from Wales.Mr Phillips, , from Welshpool, mid Wales, said: The hill is neither just Welsh, nor just English. It is a dual national hill and the strip of land that many thought a part of Wales is in fact a part of England.The border placement on the Ordnance Survey map, although very close to the summit, is still  metres from it.My conclusion is that the border should be moved.A spokesman for the Ordnance Survey said its MasterMap has the boundary correct.He added: The  maps Mr Phillips has used are guidelines only, where the boundary is m wide.We are not obliged to put a boundary in but we do so as a guide. In our most detailed mapping product the border is located accurately and correctly.Matt Redmond, deputy chief executive of the Boundary Commission for Wales, said: As far as the commission is concerned the Ordnance Survey MasterMap is the definitive boundary and it is fine.We at the Commission are content with where the boundary is.To make the changes that Mr Phillips would like to see would require primary legislation. title: jacob ress mogg people have spoken on brexit
story: Regardless of the constitutional norms or their previous votes or statements, the diehards of the Brussels Brigade blithely believe they can keep the United ­Kingdom shackled to the European Union.Three constitutional perversions have been used in this effort.The relationship between Government and Parliament is now disordered, with the House of Commons trying to do Ministers’ jobs.Collective responsibility has been abandoned so no one knows which minister speaks authoritatively for the Government’s position and, worst of all, the Referendum result, where .million people decided that we should leave, is put at nothing by the extremist ­Remainers.Next week will see this come to a head as there will be a series of Parliamentary votes to determine the future of Brexit.First, there will be another vote on Mrs May’s deal.In its current form this is unlikely to pass because of the backstop which ides the United Kingdom between Northern Ireland and Great Britain and could leave us indefinitely as a vassal state, where we have a mutual ­obligation to a superior state.Assuming this fails, then the second event would be a vote to stop a No Deal Brexit.Clearly some politicians have short memories because in ,  members of Parliament out of  voted for the law that led to March  being the date of departure, regardless of a deal or not.Cabinet ministers, who are now ­abandoning collective responsibility, voted for it, the Labour leadership voted for it, even Yvette Cooper voted for it.Yet these same people now pretend that such an outcome is an unimaginable ­horror.Even though removing the possibility of No Deal weakens the Government’s ­negotiating position and contradicts the law of the land, such a motion could pass but in itself would have no legal effect.This leaves the third vote on the issue of seeking an ­extension to our ­membership of the European Union.As yet it is unclear whatof time would be requested or what the purpose of such an extension would be.These key questions are left unanswered because the extreme Remainers do not just want an extension — they want ­reversal and see this as a first step.It is worth remembering that those who love the European Union prefer it to democracy and always have done.This is why so many other votes have been ignored in the past and why ­referendums are now so unpopular with the European elite.The Government has so far meekly accepted these developments, although Attorney General Geoffrey Cox is trying to achieve some apparently minor changes to the backstop.Instead the Government must reassert the constitutional norms.If the House of Commons will not accept the ordinary relationship between it and the Executive, then a vote of ­confidence ought to take place. If Theresa May were to win such a vote for a second time then there is no ­obligation for the Government to follow mere motions of the Commons.Similarly, ­ministers who cannot support Government policy are entitled to leave the Government, as the honourable recent example of George Eustice shows.Naturally, the Government must prove that it is committed to the referendum result, for that is the authoritative ­constitutional voice.No responsible government ought to allow the constitution to be subverted because of its own weaknesses. The ­conventions are there for good ­reasons and,ignored, confidence in the system that has served well for ­centuries will be damaged — with ­consequences that could include the rise of extremist parties. Failure to deliver Brexit would be a gt to Tommy Robinson.Fortunately, it is in the power of the Government, and especially of Mrs May, to deliver Brexit.  Votes in the House of Commons cannot override the law.If they could we would have arbitrary government and the law says we leave at the end of this month.The Prime Minister could simply refuse to ask for an extension or to move the ­Statutory Instrument that is needed to change the date. Mrs May may choose to fulfil or to break her promises to the electorate and will be held to account accordingly.Eurosceptics must similarly be guided by the electorate — it is our duty and obligation to those who trusted that the vote in  would be decisive and would be implemented.This makes it necessary to vote against the current deal as well as efforts to move the date beyond March .The people have spoken. The case ought to be concluded. Let’s have lt-off.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: macron britain right to leave eu
story: His magnicently self-important ­letter to the “Citizens of Europe” inadvertently gives the game away.“Europe is not just a market. It is a project,” he says. Well, yes. That’s the problem. It’s a project to create a European superstate we never consented to.He credits the EU with bringing “peace, prosperity and freedom”. But Nato is responsible for the peace and freedom. And prosperity hasn’t found its way to, say, Greece, or the vast numbers condemned by the euro to unemployment.And it’s hard to swallow anyway from a man whose economy is flat-lining and his cities under siege from enraged, ­yellow-vested anti-EU protesters.Macron admits the EU has problems and speaks of the “European trap”. But, incredibly, it turns out this trap is “NOT being part of the European Union”. And off he goes into a tantrum about Brexit.The icing on the cake, though, is his idea of EU reform: more Brussels control.Brilliant, Emmanuel! A few Leavers might have been wobbling. No longer.ONLY one result will prove Labour’s proposed new anti-Semitism probe has merit:Corbyn and his aides are found guilty.They and their racism are responsible for drawing Jew-haters like flies to the dung heap this once-great party now is. And some of this inner circle, claims Labour MP Margaret Hodge, intervened to weaken punishments for those racists — despite what Corbyn himself told her.He is up to his neck in anti-Semitism. Indeed, the fact Labour needs a second one at all proves what a sham hers was.Her reward for it was a peerage, with all its unelected power and money.Can Britain have a refund THERE is no point in Theresa May denying it. story: Pawel Relowicz, , was arrested five days after the student went missing after a booze-fuelled night out in January but was released pending further inquiries.However police were seen searching his home in Hull, East Yorkshire on Tuesday - around half a mile from where the student was last spotted.University of Hull student Libby was last seen on January  after a night out with friends when she was turned away from Welly nightclub in the city.Officers from Humberside Police were seen carrying evidence bags from the terraced property since am today.A Humberside Police spokesman said: Todays search forms part of an ongoing investigation.For operational reasons, we wont be confirming anymore details at this point.In a statement last week a police spokesman said Libbys disappearance remains unexplained but that their investigation is ongoing.Libby, , was last seen sitting on a bench, visibly drunk, just before midnight on January .Poor quality CCTV footage near the bench showed a man smoking by a car.Later another figure opens the passenger door and someone or something is put inside.Two police vans remain outside the house while the search is ongoing.Relowicz was held on suspicion of Libbys abduction and has been quizzed for the maximum amount of time before charges had to be brought or he had to be released.He was later charged with unrelated crimes of voyeurism, outraging public decency and burglary..pm: Libby was seen staggering around outside her student digs on Wellesley Ave.pm: CCTV captures Libby sitting on a bench on Beverley Road, close to the junction of Haworth Street. title: brits who lose out under universal credit switch should get extra cash charities say
story: Charities told MPs that claimants should even be able to go BACK onto the old systemit wasnt what they were promised.Laura Dewar, Policy Officer, Gingerbread told MPs on the Work and Pensions committee today: There must be some way of there being help,someone was given the wrong advice by the DWP, who was moved off and over, and was worse off - there must be a way of having some recompense.Campaigning MP Frank Field instructed them to look into whether the Consumer Act can apply to the troubled new benefits system, where many hundreds of thousands are set to be worse off.When someone buys a product that turned out to have not been as they were sold, Brits can apply for a refund or complain to a watchdog, it was argued.MP Steve McCabe said today: When you buy something that is not fit for purpose, you can generally get out of it within a certain period of time.Consumer protection is offered to everyone .Charities called for a flagging system to alert those thinking of switching to the new system to check with advisers first, for more training of specialist staff who understand Universal Credit, and a list of all the triggers which can send someone on to the new benefits system without their knowledge..million are expected to naturally migrate over to the new benefits system this year, even though they could be worse off.Moving house, having a child, or changing hours at work can push people to have to apply for Universal Credit.DWP boss Amber Rudd has stopped those with severe disabilities from being moved over automatically, but many others are set to do so.Single parents make up a quarter of those who have gone over naturally, Gingerbreads policy expert said.And charities warned they were all aware of people who were at a higher risk of homelessness when they went onto the new benefits programme.Maeve McGoldrick, Head of Policy and Campaigns at homeless charity crisis said: If we were going to design the transition onto Universal Credit, one of the fundamental problems is to ensure that we dont cause homelessness as a result of it.Its that drop in income, combined with delays and errors in Universal Credit, and further cuts like Local Housing Allowance, its the cumulative effect of the money they are losing, is putting housing at severe risk.The MS Society said they had definitely seen an increase in the number of calls about people worried about homelessness.She argued that Brits should be able to try Universal Credit out first before they moved over permanently - like Brits who are thinking of moving to a smart meter can do at the moment.That gives people time to prepare and consider whether they would be better off, she said.But the best way of solving the problems with Universal Credit would be to plug the title: university of glasgow buildings evacuated over suspicious package just 24 hours after bombs sent to three london transport hubs
story: The evacuations come just  hours after viable bombs were mailed to three transport hubs in London.The university confirmed at least eight buildings or offices have been evacuated after a suspect package was found in a mailroom at around .am this morning.Eye-witnesses said students were screamed at to keep away! as police formed an exclusion zone around cleared buildings.In a second incident, the Royal Bank of Scotland building in Edinburgh was also been evacuated following reports of a suspicious package at around .am today.The RBS package was found to be a  alarm around three hours later, with police confirming it contained promotional goods.Police Scotland remain at the scene at the University of Glasgow.A force spokeswoman said: Police received two reports of suspicious packages at University of Glasgow and Royal Bank of Scotland, Edinburgh.Police are in attendance and both buildings have been evacuated. At this stage there is nothing to link these incidents.They will be examined  enquiries are ongoing.University of Glasgow said the evacuated buildings would remain closed for the rest of the day.A spokesperson said: Under advice from Police Scotland, a number of buildings on the main University campus have been evacuated as a precautionary measure after a suspicious package was found in the University’s mailroom.Police are dealing with the matter and we will provide regular updates.At present, the following buildings have been closed: Boyd Orr Building, Mailroom, the OTCbuilding next to it, Wolfson Medical Building, Bower Building, Isabella Elder Building, James McCune Smith Learning Hub site and the Joseph Black Building.A letter bomb burst into flames when opened at Heathrow Airports Compass Centre, where head office staff are housed, at around .am yesterday.Further packages were then found at London City Airport and Waterloo station.All the bombs were posted in A-sized postal packages containing yellow Jfy bags and were capable of igniting when opened.Irish cops are now assisting the politan Police as the packages had a circular heart with a love from Ireland stamp on them.Security chiefs suspect the devices were a warning from the New IRA ahead of Brexit and the possibility of a hard Irish border.If the group is found to be responsible for the packages, it will be the first Republican explosives found on the mainland since .A Met Police statement said: The packages – all A-sized white postal bags containing yellow Jfy bags - have been assessed by specialist officers to be small improvised explosive devices.These devices, at this early stage of the investigation, appear capable of igniting an initially small fire when opened.The Met Police Counter Terrorism Command is treating the incidents as a linked series and is keeping an open mind regarding motives.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: braces mans teeth yellow twisted
story: Oliver Bromley-Davenport, from Bolton, Greater Manchester, claims he made  trips to the dentist after the braces he had fitted between September  and June  repeatedly snapped and fell apart, leaving his teeth in the wrong position.Oliver, who hoped the £, braces would give him the perfect smile, claims his teeth were made to look even worse than before and was only able to eat soup for weeks at a time due to the unbearable pain.After a four-year court case, dentist Dr Reesa Moosa, based at Ravat and Ray Dental Care in Bolton, settled with the -year-old support worker out of court for the five figure sum, although the dental practice did not admit liability.Dad-of-two Oliver, who has been left with permanent damage to his teeth, said: I wanted to have a little bit of work done to straighten my teeth – my front two teeth were slightly bent, but nothing dramatic.But once the braces were put on, Oliver started having problems.He said: I thought I had a high pain threshold but it just didnt seem to settle and the pain would be ongoing for four to five weeks.I just thought the pain was normal with the procedure, but it became unbearable.Eventually, I told the dentist to take them off but when I came home and showed my mum she was horried.My teeth were yellow and twisted – they looked even worse than before.Olivers braces were fitted at the end of November , but just three weeks later he ed to the dentist claiming they had become loose before a piece of metal allegedly later became dislodged, cutting into his cheek and causing it to bleed.By February , Oliver was also complaining about an emerging gap between his upper front teeth and said over the following months he was in the dentist’s chair another seven times because of the braces.He also claims he eventually discovered Dr Moosa was not a qualied orthodontist and an NHS website for the practice also described the dentist as having the Bachelor of Dental Surgery Qualication and not the higher award needed to become an orthodontist.Oliver said: As time went on and they were trying to move my teeth so much, they were adding more and more bits of metal into my mouth.The braces actually ended up being on for around  months.When they asked me how much longer I would like them on for, I thought shouldnt you be telling me when they should be removed Throughout the whole  months my teeth were never cleaned properly during each visit when the braces were removed and I was told not to worry about it.Oliver added: I was refunded the money I paid for the work, but I was later told that dentist was not a qualied orthodontist but was able to carry out orthodontic work.If I had been told that from the start I wouldnt have gone ahead with the braces.A spokesperson at Ravat and Ray Dental Care said: The practice was not involved in any court case with the patient and has not paid out any settlement in court.The aim of the practice is always to provide the best possible care to all our patients.Dr Reesa Moosa said: I cannot comment on this case because of my duty of confidentiality.

title: royal navy russian ships uk coast
story: HMS Defender was deployed over the weekend to keep watch on the frigate Admiral Gorshkov and three auxiliary ships.A Navy spokesman said: Portsmouth-based Defender is monitoring the Russian task group and keeping track of their activity in areas of national interest.Armed forces minister Mark Lancaster said: The Royal Navy is always standing ready to defend the UK.We will continue to work with our allies to shadow Russian ships passing through international waters close to our shores, to ensure the Russian navy follows the correct protocol on its journey.HMS Defender left Newcastle on Saturday to head north east of Scotland to meet the Russian task group in time for the ships to pass the UK coastline on Tuesday, and will continue to shadow the ships as they pass through the English Channel.The group comprises the frigate Admiral Gorshkov, tug Nicolay Chiker, supply ship Elbrus and tanker Kama.Commander Richard Hewitt, the commanding officer of HMS Defender, said: The security of the seas around our coastline remains crucial to our national interests.Escorting the Admiral Gorshkov has demonstrated the Royal Navys enduring commitment to protecting our home waters and readiness to undertake such tasking whenever its required.

title: permanent customs union theresa may brexit deal
story: Government discipline chief Julian Smith delivered the dramatic assessment to the Cabinet’s weekly meeting on Tuesday.Painting a stark picture for Theresa May and her top table, he said the consequencesher revised agreement is torpedoed a second time would be very serious as the Government will suffer “a loss of control”.Instead of a simple Brexit delay of up to three months to keep negotiations on the PM’s deal going, Mr Smith said rebel Tories would ally with Labour to swtly take control of the Commons order paper.An indicative vote would swtly follow for MPs to pick their preferred Brexit outcome, which he is now certain would be a softer Brexit and a customs union.Summing up his prediction, Mr Smith told the Cabinet: “A vote against the deal is a vote for delay, and a vote that will end up with a customs union”.Depressing the room further, the Chief Whip also said the Commons showdown on Tuesday was still looking “very, very tight” for the Government.Despite the increased pressure on them, the votes of around  hardline Brexiteers as well as the DUP’s  MPs were still hanging on whether Attorney General Geoffrey Cox can negotiate a clear and legally-binding escape from the Irish backstop.If her deal does fall through, Mrs May was last week forced to agree to give MPs votes on Wednesday and Thursday next week on a No Deal Brexit or a delay up to the end of June.One Cabinet Minister told The Sun on Tuesday night: “The Chief was very clear about what’s comingwe can’t win this vote. If we lose it’s out of our hands and Parliament will decide and it all gets very uncertain.“We’ll be in a customs union for a start.In more bad news for No, the DUP’s Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson told Talk Radio on Tuesday that he thought it was “very unlikely” that Mr Cox will come back with “anything that satisfies Parliament”.He blamed a Remainer Tory ministers’ revolt last week for “having thrown away the option of no deal”The Cabinet discussion came after the Foreign Secretary on Tuesday signalled that embattled Mrs May will be forced to offer Tory MPs a free vote on whether to go for a No Deal Brexit or to delay ither deal is voted downJeremy Hunt opened the door to the extraordinary scenario as feuding Tory MPs’ competing calls on the PM spiralled.Refusing Brexiteers’ demands on Tuesday to whip against any Article  extension, Mr Hunt instead warned that a Brexit deal was “the only solution”.Quizzed on a free vote, Mr Hunt said: “That is something that the Government has to make a decision on, and it is not for me to say that now”.Party grandees instead said that the Tories were so split on the issue that a free vote was the only way to avoid mass resignations from the Government form both camps.Former Tory minister Nick Boles tweeted: “Both parliamentary parties are split. title: brexit compromise ireland backstop temporary
story: Deputy PM Simon Coveney said Dublin was ready to “ensure the backstop is temporary” as Attorney General Geoffrey Cox held crunch talks with Michel Barnier in Brussels.But he also warned it was “too early to be optimistic” of a breakthrough this week, describing negotiations between the two sides as “dficult”.Mr Coveney said the two sides were “building on timelines” for when tech solutions could be introduced to reduce the need for border checks.Speaking in Dublin, he said: “We want to ensure the backstop is a temporary arrangement.“We’re in the space of trying to provide clarity that temporary means temporary.”The deputy PM said he would be “surprised”MPs voted for a no deal BrexitTheresa May fails to get her deal through Parliament next week.He added thatthe UK were to crash out “there will need to be a serious negotiations about how to avoid physical infrastructure on the border”.Mr Cox described negotiations with EU negotiators as “very constructive” as he arrived alongside Brexit secretary Steve Barclay to meet Mr Barnier.He said there were “reasonable conversations” going on about legal assurances and that there’s “always hope” for a compromise.The Government’s top lawyer presented the precise changes that Britain wants to the Brexit deal for the first time during crunch talks in Brussels last night.With just six days to go until a final Commons showdown vote, the Government’s legal chief called on the EU to accept the UK’s demand for a review mechanism for the Irish backstop.Accompanied by Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay, Mr Cox held a  minute meeting with the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier, before a working dinner.It would give a legally-binding escape route from the backstop that could otherwise trap the UK in a permanent customs union.The escape route is based around an arbitration system that would deem EU chiefs as not acting in good faiththey try to stall talks on a trade deal.But the plan risks falling short of hardline Tory Brexiteers’ demands, who have branded it “Cox’s codpiece”.No also yesterday turned down Tory eurosceptics’ demand for  hours to scrutinise the revised deal before the Commons debate on it begins on Tuesday to avoid being bounced into it.The PM’s official spokesman would only say: “We are working at pace in order to secure the changes we need. The next stage of that is the meeting that’s taking place today.“The PM fully understands that Parliamentarians will want to have time to properly scrutinise any changes that we’d secure but what I’m not able to say at the moment is precisely when we’ll be in that position.”It is understood that talks are revolving around fleshing out the details of how the UK could use a “good faith” clause to quit the backstop.Mr Coveney said new wording being thrashed out by the two sides is designed to reassure Brexiteers they can’t be “trapped” in the border fix by the EU.The Commission and UK Government both refused to discuss what happened at last night’s three-hour meeting, raising fears talks have hit the buffers.Sources said negotiations are now expected to continue throughout the week in the hopes of finding a compromise.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal brexit progress bank of england
story: Mark Carney said the Government’s accelerated contingency planning had reduced the economic damage that could follow a no deal exit.In November the Bank of England warned that Britain would be tipped into a recession worse than the financial crisis in a no deal scenario - with GDP falling by  per cent.But yesterday Mr Carney told the Lords Economic Affairs committee that “constructive developments in terms of preparedness” meant the economy may be  to . per cent lower than expected.Meanwhile Dieter Kempf, head of Germany’s biggest industry group the BDI, said delaying Brexit could be even more damaging than no deal.He said: “The Brexit issue hurts us a lot in Germany and the Netherlands. Our economies are hit hard.“My experience is that the economy can live better with bad conditions than with uncertainty.”Mr Carney warned that no deal was still likely to deliver a “material economic shock”.But he said: “Since we released those scenarios in November there have been some constructive developments in terms of preparedness - some of them have been detailed over the course of the last few weeks in terms of broader parliamentary testimony.”Mr Carney explained: “If you took the scenarios that we had for a no-deal Brexit and you referenced the disruptive and the disorderly, and it depends what your counterfactual is - so what are we comparing it to -we compare those as we did in November to our forecast of the economy at the time which presumed something broadly consistent with the Prime Minister’s deal... the potential hit to GDP was just under % in the disruptive and just under % in the disorderly.“The items I indicated earlier, given our modelling of the situation, would pull back somewhere between % to .% of those losses depending on the scenario.”He added: “There has been progress in preparedness and that reduces the level of the economic shock.”Meanwhile the head of the civil service in Northern Ireland said that a no deal Brexit could cause a sharp rise in unemployment in the region.Inability to prepare, EU tarfs and signicant changes to exports could cause business distress, failure or the relocation of some companies to the Republic, a report from David Sterling said.He added: “The consequences of material business failure as a result of a ‘no-deal’ exit, combined with changes to everyday le and potential border frictions could well have a profound and long-lasting impact on society.“The planning assumptions include the possibility that, in some scenarios, a no-deal exit could result in additional challenges for the policethe approach appeared to be unfair or unreasonable for some of those most affected.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit trade deal chlorinated chicken
story: Trump ally Woody Johnson hit out at the campaign to demonise American food such as chlorine-washed chicken.He insisted US products are perfectly safe and said Britain would have to open its borders to them as part of a post-Brexit deal.Mr Johnson told the BBC: To get a robust agreement that lts all boats it needs to include farming.A lot of these statements are designed - perhaps by the EU - to create barriers to American farm products.I think the campaign against American farm products has been very successful, talking about chlorine and so on, but its really designed to reduce trade and not increase trade.Most Americans would feel our food is safe and cost-effective and humane.Campaigners have demanded that existing bans on chlorinated chicken and hormone-treated beef remain in place after Brexit.They claim the practices are evidence that the US has lower standards for animal welfare.Today George Eustice, who quit as Farming Minister last month, said American agriculture is quite backward.He wrote in the : If the Americans want to be granted privileged access to the UK market, then they will have to learn to abide by British law and British standards, or they can kiss goodbye to any trade deal and join the back of the queue.Trade Secretary Liam Fox says a deal with the US is one of his top priorities after Brexit.But Michael Gove has vowed to block any weakening of Britains existing food standards.Malcolm Turnbull, an old friend of Theresa May’s from Oxford, told MPs in Westminster last night that Britain should get stuck into trade talks wherever it can because “history is made by those who turn up”.When asked for his advice on how Britain can strike trade deals across the world after we leave, he said: “I think Britain has to look at the whole world as its oyster.”He said Mrs May could expect “every encouragement from us” as we break free from the bloc, and urged her to remember “we live in a very small world”.“[We are] nowhere as far away from anywhere ,” he told an event held by the Henry Jackson Society. “It takes you far less time to get to Tokyo or Sydney than our grandparents took to get to France.”Free trade was hard to sell politically in an age of populism, he argued, but Australia has been successful in making the case.“We have got to be prepared to say trade means jobs. Got to go out to background and factory, farm after farm and point to the men and women whose jobs depend on access to markets,” he said.Mr Turnbull, who served as Australia’s PM from  to , also used his speech to warn Britain to be wary of cyber threats from China - through companies such as Huawei.

story: NewsBrexit: UK could slash % of tarfs in No Deal risking flood of importsThe move, which hasnt been confirmed by the government, would open the door to a stream of cheap imports that could undermine UK manufacturingShareCommentsByRyan WilkinsonDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR NewsThe sweeping reduction would see tarfs slashed on between % and % of imports, according to Sky News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tarfson vast swathes of imports to the UK could be slashed in a No Deal Brexit , it emerged last night.The sweeping reduction would seetarfsslashed on between % and % of imports, according to Sky News. title: frances ogrady theresa mays brexit
story: NewsopinionFrances OGrady: Theresa Mays Brexit promises on workers rights are worthlessFrances OGrady, general secretary of the TUC, says Theresa Mays proposals wont even guarantee existing employment rights after Brexit, let alone improve themShareCommentsByFrances OGrady:,  MAR NewsopinionFrances OGrady says a future Tory government could tear up workers rights altogether "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhat planet is the prime minister living on  She wants us to believe that under her government, Britain is leading the way on workers’ rights. Tell that to the millions who haven’t seen a real pay rise for years and are stuck in jobs where their bosses have the whip hand. The flimsy proposals she’s unveiled today won’t even guarantee your existing rights after Brexit. And they certainly won’t stop workers’ rights in the UK from falling behind those in the rest of Europe. Theresa May says our rights at work won’t be watered down. But her promises are worthless when she is unlikely to be in post this time next year. And there’s nothing to stop a future right-wing Tory government from tearing these rules up altogether. In January, I met with Theresa May and I was clear that when it comes to jobs and workers’ rights, warm words wouldn’t cut it. After all, we’re talking about hard-won protections that really matter to working people. Paid holidays, time off for mums and dads, equal pay for women, limits on working hours.   Working people need a cast-iron, legal guarantee that rights like these will be safe after Brexit, and that guarantee should be written into the deal. But instead of a binding guarantee, all the prime minister has offered is yet more weasel words. She’s asking us to trust that her government and her party will protect our rights at work. But why should working people trust the party that introduced employment tribunal fees that priced thousands of low-paid workers out of justice  That made it easier for bosses to sack people by doubling the qualying period for unfair dismissal  That refuses to ban zero-hours contracts even though they’re ruining people’s lives  That’s not what leading the world on workers’ rights looks like. Today’s announcement doesn’t change anything. MPs must not be taken in by this blatant window dressing. Our hard-won rights are still under threat.

The Home Secretary declared a new rash of people attempting to come into the UK on dinghies across the Channel in January a ‘major incident’. But Foreign Office Minister Alistair Burt told the Mirror: “I think we ought to bear proportions in mind. “A quarter of Lebanon’s population is refugee. If you’re in Altrincham, that’s rather less likely.” Home Secretary Sajid Javid declared a major incident over Christmas after  migrants were picked up in the English Channel. This dropped to just  in January.   In the latest incident, a boat carrying  suspected migrants, including a baby and two children was intercepted by Border Force last Tuesday morning. story: NewsUniversal Credit: Woman had suicidal thoughts after joining benefit, MPs hearFamilies who have a change in circumstances are moved to the six-in-one benefit without transition paymentsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video woman-left-suicidal-thoughts-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A vulnerable woman was left with suicidal thoughts after joining Universal Credit with no transition payments, MPs heard today.A charity worker called for reforms after warning the woman, named only as Emma, found it very dficult and needed a lot of help from friends and family. The shocking example came as MPs discussed so-called natural migration to the six-in-one benefit system. Existing benefit claimants are being spared a move to UC until , and will be given transition payments to avoid their income suddenly dropping. But those who have a change in circumstances now are moved immediately without those payments.   Charities told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee the drop in income often happened for unfair reasons and increased the risk of homelessness. Laura Dewar, Policy Officer at Gingerbread, said it was “unfair” and “pretty arbitrary” that people don’t get protection “just because of the timing of it”. Anastasia Berry of the MS Society said triggers for switching to UC are often “unavoidable, unnecessary and out of somebody’s control” - at a time when someone is struggling anyway. Ayaz Manji, Senior Policy and Campaigns Officer at mental health charity Mind, said the problem was not simply UC - but a combination of changes at once. He told MPs: “When you talk about financial losses that can be anywhere, on the lower end and probably more unusually, about pound a month but more often than that we’re seeing pound,  sometimes more a month particularly for people who are in work.  “It’s very hard to see this as a neat or clean edge of winners and losers on the balance sheet “Because often what’s happening is when people are naturally migrating, an awful lot of other things are happening at the same time. “A colleague at a local Mind was talking to me about one of their clients named Emma. “She ended up naturally migrating after having a PIP reassessment and losing her entitlement to PIP. “And she ended up as a result of all that being worse off by about pound a month. “But at the same time HMRC had discovered a historic overpayment so her first UC claim was about pound less than it should be. “She was asked to go for another WCA after migrating even though that shouldn’t have happened “And as a result of all these pressures happening at the same time in transition, she started to develop suicidal thoughts during that time. “She found it very dficult even to engage with the advisor at the local Mind to carry on attending her appointments. “And she actually needed quite a lot of help from friends and family.” He added: We do need to see natural migration paused in a greater range of circumstances.” Charities warned of the risk of homelessness. Maeve McGoldrick, Head of Policy and Campaigns at Crisis, said: It’s that drop in income combined with the delays and errors in Universal Credit and combined with other cuts, particularly LHA. It’s the cumulative impact of the money you’re losing is putting housing at severe risk. Anastasia Berry of the MS Society said there had “definitely” been an increase in risk of homelessness. “Our helpline has said they’ve seen in increase in the number of calls around homelessness, she said. Early results from a survey that closed last week showed % borrowed from family or friends and % borrowed from a loan or credit cards, she said. She added: “A person with MS told us they’ve had to use food banks to feed their family, they’re now  months behind on council tax andit wasn’t for their mother in law they would have been evicted because they couldn’t pay the rent.” Laura Dewar, Policy Officer at Gingerbread, said for some people “housing associations have stepped in and are letting there be a pause in rent”. The Department for Work and Pensionshas been contacted for comment.Samaritans operates a -hour service available every day of the year. If you prefer to write down how you’re feeling, oryou’re worried about being overheard on the phone, you can email Samaritans at jo@samaritans.org.

title: mans double life exposed two
story: NewsMans double le was exposed when TWO girlfriends met over his hospital bed - then they healed each others heartsKathleen Maloney, , was devastated after discovering her partner of five years had spent the last  years with Susan - before both women decided to help each other through their painShareCommentsByKathleen Maloney:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsKathleenand Susanhelped one another through the pain and heartache "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBubbles. Susan and I laughed until our sides hurt at the nickname we had both been given. Id once thought of it as affectionate and sweetly romantic - but now the moniker which tied me to this wonderful woman stood for nothing but lies. Well were good women - and now he has lost both of us, we told one another. We were duped by Anthony. I had made le-changing decisions for this man in the name of a very misplaced love. But, through our pain, loss and deep betrayal, Susan and I found one another.   I met Anthony in , and was smitten from the first dinner date when he took me to a fancy restaurant on the ocean front. He was ft, extremely handsome and, even better - a true gentleman. Id got lucky with this one. He opened every door, paid for every date and after that first dinner, he gently placed his coat over my shoulders as we walked along the sea-front. I was during those heady, wonderful first few weeks and months of our relationship that I fell for him. It was surreal - like something out of a movie. It felt wonderful to feel those butterflies again. He made me feel beautul, showering me with affection. But something didnt feel entirely right from the beginning. He would disappear for weeks at a time without warning, and when I suggested he didnt feel as strongly about me, he told me his feelings actually ran so deep for me, it frightened him. Ive never met a good woman like you before, he would tell me. The periods away continued, but after two years of dating, we grew incredibly close and began talking about our future together. We planned our future in the sunshine, we laughed together, we held hands while eating at restaurants - we were in love.   A year passed by and despite our undeniable chemistry, I still felt something wasnt right and Anthony wasnt fully letting me into his le. I asked him about why I hadnt met any of his children, so he invited his son to join us for dinner - although he was always too busy. Never dreaming this man could go on to hurt me so badly, I went on to honour his request to join his church as a way of proving my commitment. My commitment  It really all seems laughable now. But I did just that, and joined in the hope of one day becoming his we. Though I still had some unease about our relationship, I felt more confident because he asked me to be a part of something I knew was incredibly meaningful to him. Then came the call that would change everything, shattering this so-called love story to pieces. Wed been together for five years, and Anthony had gone into hospital for minor surgery. The operation went well, he told me assuredly in the unexpected phone call. I thought your surgery was scheduled for tomorrow I said, surprised and confused how he hadnt filled me in. Anthony told me doctors had managed to move it forward a day, adding that he was in quarantine for a few more days so it wouldnt be worth visiting. But this was the man I loved, laying in hospital, alone and in pain.   I did what any caring person would and hopped in the car, drove the two hours to his hospital to pay him a surprise visit. And what a surprise it turned out to be - for us all. After checking in and receiving my visitors pass, I took the lt to the sixth floor and I made my way to Anthonys room. A nurse was working on him, so I said hello to him from across the room. Something was obviously not right - Anthony meekly replied hello, but seemed quiet and cold towards me. He had never acted like this around me before and this was not the man I knew. I recognised Anthonys son sat at his bedside from pictures, but couldnt place the woman he was chatting to. She smiled warmly at me and even got up to give me her seat before pulling a spare chair over and sitting down again. We made small talk about the beautul view of Manhattan from Anthonys hospital window. She was easy to talk to and I instantly liked her. We even shared a few laughs before I started the introductions. Im Kathy, by the way. Im Susan, she replied, holding out her hand with a warm smile. In the moments that followed, I had no idea Id grow to love that welcoming, kind smile - a hint at the beautul person she is. Susan - the name rattled around my head. I thought back to a year earlier when Anthony had mentioned his ex-girlfriends name was Susan.   He assured me then that their relationship was long over, telling me I have no idea what happened to her. I didnt want to act too hastily, but instead tried making small talk with Anthony - who by this point refused to engage with me and seemed really tense. I had to get to the bottom of this. “So, how long have you known Anthony  I asked Susan. For eighteen years., she replied frankly. My stomach dropped. I askedwe could talk in the corridor, hearing Anthony mumble, Oh brother, here we go. Here comes the pow-wow, as we left. Alone in the hallway, we told each other everything. I told Susan I had been in a relationship with Anthony for the past five years. I told her how he often discussed our future together and how he had suggested we move somewhere warm like South Carolina. Susans face grew more and more distraught as I continued to tell her about my relationship with him. Then came my turn. Susan took a deep breath before telling me she had been in a committed relationship with Anthony for eighteen years and had even gone shopping for engagement rings before his surgery. I couldnt believe what I was hearing. My le as Id come to know it had ended in this cold hospital hallway.   Then my heart broke all over again - this time, for Susan. Susan asked meAntony ever criticised me, put me down, critiqued my clothes, make-up and body shape. I was stunned, but after promising her Id be % honest, I told Susan that Anthony had made me feel beautul. And he did. He had always treated me with respect and kindness. He was gentle, loving and soft-spoken with me. Susan outlined a very dferent side to him I had never known. I asked Susan, How did we not run into each other at Anthonys home  Didnt you see the bar of Irish Spring soap I left in his shower  She rolled her eyes, I used it, she replied. The more we talked, the more we learned about the two lives Anthony had been living and how he kept us apart. Susan was a good-looking woman who seemed smart and caring, so I asked her why she hadnt left. She didnt respond, but stared blankly at the floor of the hallway. I assured her my relationship with Anthony would end, before walking back into his room to collect my things. I told Anthony everything, but he had nothing to say. He knew it was over.   As I was about to leave, something incredible happened. Anthonys son stopped me, apologised for his fathers behavior and askedhe could hug me. I drove home in a daze, thinking of Susan, wondering why she had stayed with him all these years. She deserved so much better -we both did. I was broken hearted and I felt physically sick for days after that afternoon in the hospital. Discovering Anthony was a player and a liar hit me hard. How could I have been so gullible  Did he think we would never find out what he was doing  My mind was racing with so many questions. Two months after our chance meeting in the hospital, Susan looked up my number and reached out to me. She told me that she had some more questions for me and I answered all of them the best that I could. Susan said she had hoped to marry Anthony one day, but he always had a reason why he wouldnt go through with the wedding - and it was usually a cruel one. Our regular chats on the phone soon turned to topics outside of our ex. We lted each other up and the more we learned about each other, the more we liked.

story: AdvertorialHow you can get supermarket shopping for a THIRD of the priceNew initiative also helps people with their finances with free budget adviceShareByDave Masters:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR AdvertorialMembers are able to take advantage of the scheme for up to six months while they find their feet "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pioneering community cafe is transforming lives by offering discounted shopping and hot meals, employment help and financial advice. Cafe Number  is a membership-based, not-for-profit citizens supermarket and cafe. The outlet sells surplus food donated from supermarkets at a discount, with prices at least two-thirds lower than a normal shop. It also serves wholesome, healthy and affordable meals where a family of four can dine for under pound. And after visitors have completed their shopping, they can sit with a coffee and speak to specialist advisors who will help get them back into work, or work with them to consolidate their debt into a manageable payment. The team at the cafe, which is based in Birkenhead, Merseyside, also offer interview techniques, help with improving CVs and even secure them work. “The idea is that we help people help themselves. They stay with us until we sort them out and when they are flourishing, they can move on,” said project coordinator Andrew Forsey.  “We also want to enable people on low incomes to access affordable food in a dignied and welcoming environment. Andrew works with Birkenhead’s independent MP Frank Field, and the cafe is run in partnership with Feeding Birkenhead, a coalition of local community groups. “A driving force is to offer an intervention to people. For someone who is struggling from week to week, it can sometimes just take one event like a broken fridge or unexpected large bill to find yourself in crisis. So shopping with us for a while will help keep them ticking over while we can advise over how best to get a grip of underlying debt problems.” Members are able to take advantage of the scheme for up to six months while they find their feet. “We are working with around  iniduals and their families,” said Andrew. “These are people that were mostly referred by a local housing association but in future we are working with people who come to us from job center.” In the future the centre hopes to help in other areas, like cookery classes. “We have had members tell us, that they buy the food but could do with help with ideas of how to make meals, so that is something we will look to launch soon too.” Staff and volunteers at Number  have also been specically chosen from the community. Those who have been out of work for a while or who need a confidence boost have been employed. Andrew added: “An unexpected boost has been the benefit to people’s mental health, those who have felt isolated and have come here for a shop, a meal, a coffee, have reported feeling uplted.”For more Stories of Local Pride, click here

You know thatyou don’t stand for something you’ll fall for anything. So let that be your true north, let that be your call to action -to inspire those who stand for nothing, to stand for something -and to stand WITH you. So what’s next, what’s on your to-do list starting now... Be braver Be stronger Be kind to each other Be kind to yourselves Have less screen time, and more face to face time Exceed expectations Eliminate plastics Conserve water Protect wildle and their unique habitat Keep empathy alive Ask your friends how they are doing and listen to the answer Be honest Take risks Change your thoughts and change the world Dare to be thegreatest generation of all time I am with you, we are with you!

story: NewsMoment builder shouts whoop as he bulldozes retirement homes with diggerDaniel Neagu, , went on a  minute rampage following a row over £, in unpaid wages and has been jailed for four yearsShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video moment-builder-shouts-whoop-bulldozes-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA builder who filmed himself shouting whoop whoop as he destroyed five new build bungalows with a digger was today jailed for four years. Daniel Neagu, , went on a  minute rampage - with music blaring from the cab radio - following a row over pound, in unpaid wages. He used a GoPro camera and an iPhone to film himself swearing, whistling the tune to Freed From Desire and saying: Beautul houses, you have to take it down and rebuild it, thats because you didnt want to pay me. Judge Stephen Warner heard over pound, of damage was caused to the five McCarthy and Stone retirement cottages. He said unknown onlookers who encouraged Neagu should be ashamed of their conduct. Sentencing, the judge said the footage was truly shocking, adding: Its quite clear from your demeanour that you were perfectly relaxed and quite unashamed.  This was planned, deliberate and wanton vandalism involving the destruction of other peoples property undertaken by you as a pure act of revenge. It caused financial loss on a very signicant scale. Romanian Neagu, who came to the UK in , broke onto the building site in Buntingford, Herts., on August  last year. He claimed subcontractor building firm Fentons owed his business Danny Boy Ltd pound,.  But St Albans Crown Court heard Fentons withheld the money after one of its vehicles, which was fitted with a tracker, ended up in Romania. Prosecutor Richard Hutchings played the judge footage that Neagu shot from the digger cab as he carried out his wrecking spree. The defendant covered his face in the dock as he watched the blue-armed digger with scoop bucket crash into  three-bed and  two-bed bungalows, smashing them down to the foundations. He could be heard shoutingf***ing s*** company and sang the dance song Oh Nar Nar as he took his revenge.   He told onlookers: I dont blame you for calling the police. They ask for pound, for these homes. They dont have pound, to pay . I wanted to give them a lesson. Hertfordshire police arrived and he was arrested.   He told officers he did not have the money to pay six employees, causing his family to be threatened. Neagu said he took Fentons van to Romania but claimed it would be ed when he was paid, adding: They have to learn not to take the piss out of the workers. The cost of the destruction, in excess of pound,, did not include rebuilding the two and three-bedroom houses. Insurers covered the cost of the bungalows, which were marketed for pound, for a two-bedroom and pound, for a three-bedroom. New owners of the properties were just weeks away from moving in when the attack happened.  Neagu, of Harrow, north-west London, initially denied criminal damage but changed his plea in January. His lawyer Andrew Campbell said he was provoked and called a midget and a gypsy by bosses who he confronted about payment. He added: It is an extraordinary case. He provided the evidence against himself. He had carried out these actions as a public demonstration that he had not been paid. Theres a strange sort of logic in it, but theres a logic in it.

title: mum spent almost 50 minutes
story: NewsMum spent almost  minutes on phone before finding baby drowned in bathSarah Elizabeth Morris, from Bagilit in Flintshire left daughter Rosie and her twin brother in the bath unattended while she talked to her partner, jurors heardShareByLydia Morris:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSarah Morris was on the phone to her partner while her twin children were in the bath unattended, jurors heard "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA one-year-old baby drowned when she was left unattended in a bath while her mum was on the phone, a court heard. Sarah Elizabeth Morris was talking to her partner when daughter Rosie,  months, drowned. Morris, , has been charged with manslaughter and child cruelty, which she denies, North Wales Live reports. Rosie was left in the bath for prolonged periods, Mold Crown Court in Wales was told on the first day of Morris trial. The court heard that the mum - who has been unable to provide a clear account of what happened - was on the phone to her then partner Sarah Swindles for almost  minutes while her children were in the bath. Oliver Saxby, prosecuting, told jurors that Morris, who had been popping her head around the door on occasion, had gone to check on the twins after Ms Swindles advised her to do so.  But when she did, she discovered Rosie had downed. Morris, from Bagilit in Flintshire, Wales, called her friend Jemma Egerton, who she had known for about a month, to tell her that Rosie wasnt breathing and that she didnt know what had happened to her, the court heard. After almost  minutes on the phone, Ms Egerton ended the call by advising Morris to dial . Instead, Morris rushed into the street holding Rosie upside down and shouting for help, leaving her son in the bath. Her neighbour Christine Murphy called for help before taking them both back inside. There were prolonged periods when she was not checking on them and had forgotten about them and the danger they were in, said Mr Saxby.  Neither baby had any child support with them in the bathroom to stabilise or prevent them from falling over. They were left in an extremely vulnerable position. As a result of her failure to supervise the twins as they sat unsupported, one of them drowned. In a police interview following the incident, Morris said that, before she found her daughter, she was in the kitchen doing the washing and heating the towels so they they were warm when they got out of the bath. She told officers that it was after she had been for a cigarette in her bedroom that she thought she heard the plug being pulled in the bath. Morris said she went to look and that was when she found Rosie lying on her back in the bath. She said she performed CPR on her daughter before running out into the street for help. The court heard she told doctors at the hospital where Rosie was taken that she had only left the children for five minutes to get some towels when she found her daughter lying in the bath on her back. The trial continues.
